awd_abstract_narration:
This project establishes a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Internet of Things (IoT) security at Dakota State University (DSU) in Madison, South Dakota. The REU site will host 10 students on DSU's campus to participate in a 10-week summer program each year of the project. The program provides unique frontline cybersecurity research experiences in IoT, professional development, close student interactions, and follow-up activities in order to build participants' knowledge and confidence for work in the cybersecurity field. The students will work closely with faculty mentors to conduct IoT security research projects. The project will recruit a highly skilled and diverse group of students. 

The selected REU research projects focus on cloud-based IoT applications and aim to ensure end-to-end trust and security. IoT presents many new challenges for security including scalability, system constraints, and enlarged attack surfaces. This project will create dynamic testing approaches to collect network characteristics and application payload data from IoT devices. The collected data will be further analyzed to assess the vulnerabilities of IoT devices and security risks in IoT. Student researchers will develop new solutions to mitigate security risks found in IoT. The outcomes of the research projects will address the current and urgent needs to resolve security and privacy issues in IoT.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site in IoT Security at Dakota State University provides undergraduate students with frontline cybersecurity research experiences in Internet of Things (IoT). The objectives of this REU site include 1) prepare and nurture a highly skilled group of students with research experiences on innovative IoT security issues; 2) recruit female students and students from institutions with limited cybersecurity research opportunities. Among the 30 students who participated in the summer programs, 10 of REU participants are female students, and 12 of the REU participants are minority students, 7 from Doctoral Universities with high and very high research activity, 3 from Doctoral/Professional Universities, 17 from Master's Colleges & Universities, 4 from Baccalaureate Colleges, and 2 from community colleges, according to the Carnegie Classifications Data File released on June 17, 2022. Twenty-three out of thirty of the participants in this REU site were from universities with limited cybersecurity research opportunities. 

REU participants have worked closely with research mentors to develop novel approaches and techniques for securing the IoT. REU participants gained valued skills through cybersecurity seminars and professional development workshops. The research projects in this REU site have led to four publications. The four publications include eleven student co-authors and three research mentors. Two publications were nominated by the conference technical program committees for the best paper awards and one publication received the best paper award. The REU participants also created sixteen research posters and presented their research posters at the SD EPSCoR Undergraduate Research Symposium. In addition, the REU participants created six vulnerability disclosure reports. These six disclosure reports have been shared with the corresponding vendors. Among the 30 REU participants in 2019 and 2022, 8 students went to graduate schools. Due to the pandemic, the project was not able to host the summer program in 2020. However, this REU Site was able to operate as normal in 2021 and 2022. The in-person summer programs provided great experiences for all REU participants. They gained not only valuable cybersecurity skills, but also critical people skills through collaborations and interactions with each other.

An independent evaluator conducted the program evaluation each year of the project. Based on the students? self-reported gains in various research skills between 2019 and 2022, the evaluation results revealed our REU participants gained significant skills in the following areas: designing experiments, determining the next step in a research project, identifying limitations of research methods and designs, keeping a detailed lab notebook, understanding the connections among scientific and engineering disciplines, and writing scientific reports or papers.
